text: UPPER QUATERNARY SEAFLOOR MASS-TRANSPORT DEPOSITS AT THE
BASE OF SLOPE, OFFSHORE NIGER DELTA, DEEPWATER NIGERIA

JASON P. SUTTON
RWE Dea UK, 90 High Holborn, London WC1V 6LJ, U.K.

AND
ROBERT M. MITCHUM, JR.
Chevron Corporation, 1600 Smith Street, Houston, Texas, 77002, U.S.A.

ABSTRACT: Deepwater mass-transport deposits (MTDs) are associated with Upper Quaternary seafloor leveed-channel complexes at the
mouth of a large canyon at the base of slope of the offshore Niger delta. They make excellent analogs for interpreting older subsurface
features and reservoirs, and for geohazard analysis. These leveed-channel complexes and mass-transport deposits are assessed within a
3D seismic survey, using detailed images of seafloor maps and stratal surfaces, artificially digitally colored, and vertically exaggerated to
create optimal imaging. A large canyon head incises the present-day shelf margin of the Niger delta and traverses down the upper and lower
slope for 45 km towards the southeast. At the canyon mouth, a large apron of leveed-channel complexes covers the slope and basin plain
for a distance of 30 km within the seismic survey. Large sediment waves occur on outer levees of channel bends, attaining heights of 200
m. In some areas, synclinal limbs of individual sediment waves have been deformed by numerous rotated blocks along small listric faults
to form small mappable MTDs.

Other mass-transport deposits occur associated with and above the leveed-channel complexes. Lengths of the MTDs range from 1 km
to over 16 km, and thicknesses commonly range from 100 m to 200 m. Headward escarpments are well imaged in both map and cross-section
views. Proximal facies of the MTDs includes rotated blocks and large angular glide blocks. These pass distally into smaller glide blocks and
chaotic seismic facies inferred to be debrites. Intermediate parts of the MTDs have longitudinal linear features parallel to inferred flow
direction. Distal patterns consist of transverse compressive ridges. Other MTDs too large to be completely imaged within the 3D survey
show internal facies, consisting of large angular glide blocks in a matrix of seismically visible smaller blocks and chaotic facies inferred to
be debrites. Multiple causes of MDTs in this area are probable. In possible order of importance, these include tilting and oversteepening
of sediments because of tectonic uplift, high sedimentation rates at the mouth of the canyon, and eustatic falls of sea level.
KEY WORDS: Upper Quaternary, seafloor, mass-transport deposits, MTDs, base of slope, offshore Niger Delta, deepwater Nigeria, leveed-

channel deposits, sediment waves, seismic facies, debrites, digital enhancement, volume rendering,  pressure ridges, lateral
flow lines, shear zones, fault scarp, rotated blocks, thrust blocks

Mass-transport deposits (MTDs) form significant propor-
tions of deepwater sediments worldwide. They are being more
thoroughly studied than in the past because of hazards of mass
failures of the continental slope and at deepwater drilling sites, as
well as their significance in hydrocarbon exploration and devel-
opment. MTDs include a wide spectrum of gravity-induced
deposits, including slides, slumps, and debrites, but generally
excluding turbidites such as leveed-channel complexes and sheet
deposits (Moscardelli et al., 2006). Terminology can be confusing
(Shanmugam et al., 1995). MTDs and turbidites can occur inter-
bedded in the same depositional regimes, and MTDs can severely
impact turbidite reservoir continuity and productivity
(Moscardelli et al., 2006).

This paper illustrates seafloor examples of MTDs and their
interrelationships with turbidite leveed-channel complexes us-
ing a 3D seismic survey in offshore deepwater Nigeria. Deposits
illustrated are at or directly below the seafloor. High-frequency,
near-surface 3D seismic data give depositional detail not possible
in deeper data, and can serve as analogs for seismic interpretation
at reservoir depths. Sediment thicknesses and depths presented
in isopach maps and seismic time sections are obtained from a
depth-migrated seismic data set not presented in the paper.

Mass-Transport Deposits in Deepwater Settings
SEPM Special Publication No. 96, Copyright © 2011
SEPM (Society for Sedimentary Geology), ISBN 978-1-56576-287-9, p. 85–110.

The seismic survey is approximately 100 km offshore and is
approximately 35 km by 50 km in size (Figs. 1, 2). Sediments
included in the survey occur in deep water at the toe of slope of
the Niger delta depocenter. They consist of Upper Quaternary
slope, canyon, and basin deposits which are strongly controlled
by underlying regional structural trends associated with the
deposition of the Niger delta (Fig. 1).

Overall morphology of the present-day Niger delta and re-
lated deepwater sediments consists of shelf, slope, and basin-
plain configuration, defined by seafloor bathymetric trends. Well-
defined seafloor structural trends suggest present-day structural
activity, especially in the outer thrust trends (Fig. 1) (Mitchum
and Wach, 2002). The present-day shelf margin is cut by canyons
and gullies that provide sediment paths to the basin during
relative lowstands of sea level (Fig. 1). Upper slope areas, under-
lain by diapir and inner toe-thrust structural trends, are zones of
channel erosion and bypass. Lower slope areas, between the
inner and outer thrust trends, contain leveed-channel complexes in
local intraslope basins. The channels exhibit erosion and bypass in
areas of active thrusts and tear faults. The basin plain outboard of
the outer thrust trend contains large well-developed leveed-chan-
nel complexes. The central reentrant in the outer thrust trend is a
major depocenter of leveed-channel complexes fed through a
relatively large canyon. The 3D seismic survey of the present
FIG. 1.—Shaped bathymetric map of offshore Niger delta and related deepwater sediments. Generalized Upper Quaternary leveed-

channel complexes on the seafloor and immediate substrata are shown. Depositional patterns conform to shelf, upper slope, lower
slope, and basin-plain configuration. Study area is located in a central reentrant of the basin plain into the lower slope. Green, blue,
yellow, and red colors differentiate separate groups of leveed-channel complexes. After Mitchum and Wach (2002). Reprinted
with permission of the Gulf Coast Section SEPM Foundation.

aries. Two major leveed-channel complexes occur on the seafloor,
one to the far left (west), and a later channel formed by evulsion
from the first near the canyon mouth. Slumping of walls of the
canyon appear as cuspate surfaces along the canyon walls. The
large area to the east of the leveed-channel complexes consists
mostly of MTDs. This area has a rough surface, in which inter-
preted flow patterns can be observed, especially to the right. All
of these areas are be described in more detail.

study area is located at the mouth of the canyon which is a feeder
system for leveed-channel complexes and related sediments.

An oblique view of the seafloor included in the 3D seismic
survey (Fig. 2) illustrates the setting for many of the features to be
described in more detail below. The canyon mouth cuts the slope
at the top of the figure. Two leveed-channel complexes on the
seafloor emerge from the canyon and build out to the southwest.
At least three other leveed-channel complexes below the seafloor
occur in the central area. Mass-transport deposits in the central
and eastern parts of the area are described below.

The overall rectilinear pattern bounding the edges of major
development of leveed-channel complexes and MTDs appears to
focus at the canyon mouth, and to follow the base of the slope at
a low angle (Fig. 3). Beyond this boundary to the east, the seafloor
is smoother and less disturbed, indicating fewer MTDs. This
distribution of MTDs may be controlled by a combination of
factors, such as greater sedimentation rates at the canyon mouth,
or enhancement by continued seaward structural tilting of the
seafloor until the slope reaches the point of mass failure (see
discussion below).

A coherency map of the seafloor within the 3D seismic survey
grid shows several key features (Fig. 3), and provides an over-
view of the setting for the mass-transport deposits and leveed-
channel complexes described in this paper. A narrow, deep
canyon mouth at the top of the map (northeast) opens out into a
depocenter with rectilinear boundaries trending west and south-
east from the canyon mouth, at a low angle to the base of slope.
Nearly all of the MTDs in the area occur south of these bound-

Leveed-channel complexes 1–5 (oldest to youngest) emanating
from the canyon mouth dominate the area (Fig. 4). Leveed-channel
FIG. 2.—Oblique 3-D overview of the present-day seafloor derived from a 3D grid at the toe of the deepwater Niger Delta (Fig. 1). Major

leveed-channel complexes occur at the mouth of a large canyon. Associated mass-transport deposits occur in a broad area adjacent
to and interbedded with the channel systems. Seismic survey is approximately 50 km by 35 km in size.
FIG. 3.—Coherency map of the seafloor within 3D seismic survey. Sharp breaks (faults) and steep dips are mapped as dark colored,

low coherence. Low dips are highly coherent, with light colors. Features of canyon mouth, leveed-channel complexes, and mass-
transport deposits are present. Two leveed-channel complexes dominate the western area. The eastern area has MTDs on the
seafloor interpreted as debrites. The central area has larger MTDs with an irregular surface interpreted as large slide blocks within
MTDs. Most MTDs occur south of a southeast-trending shear zone to the east. Slumping occurs as rotated blocks in canyon walls.
Map dimensions are approximately 35 km by 50 km.
FIG. 4.—Coherency map of the seafloor, overlaid by a diagram of leveed-channel complexes (channel fills are yellow and levees are

brown), on and below the sea floor. Channel fills and levees are numbered 1–5 from oldest to youngest. Channel fills 1–3 are below
the seafloor, and channel fills 4–5 are on the seafloor. Wavy arcuate lines on the levee associated with channel fill 1 represent
sediment waves which have been deformed by localized rotated blocks (study area 1). Cross section (red line) shows location of
Figure 6. Map is 35 km by 50 km in size.

complexes 1 to 3 are buried immediately under the seafloor, and do
not have bathymetric expression. Leveed-channel complexes 4
and 5 are on the seafloor (Fig. 3). Related levee systems of buried
channel-fills 1-3 are not evident on the seafloor but are shown in
brown in Figure 3. Leveed-channel complex 1 has well-developed
sediment waves (black wavy lines), which are imaged in greater
detail below (study area 1). These sediment waves have been
deformed by localized slumping in the form of rotated blocks,
which appear as early stages of mass transport of sediment. Lev-
eed-channel complexes 1 and 2 have been buried by younger
MTDs (Fig. 5), which are presented in greater detail below.

initiation point of the MTD. Pressure ridges may be formed by
elongate thrust blocks in the terminal part of the MTD. In this
paper, pressure ridges were also formed in the chaotic seismic
facies interpreted as debrites. Longitudinal linear features inter-
preted as lateral flow lines were observed in some MTDs. In
addition, rotated blocks deforming sediment waves on levees of
leveed-channel complexes were classified as MTDs, because they
are areally mappable and form a sequence-stratigraphic facies
pattern on levee surfaces.

A schematic cross section shows the relative ages, locations,
and features of the five leveed-channel complexes, and their
relationship to the areas of MTDs studied (Fig. 6). The diagram of
leveed-channel complex 1 illustrates the location of large sedi-
ment waves on its eastern levee.

Three key areas of the 3D seismic survey are described in
greater detail to illustrate the various types of mass-transport
deposits described in the study. Area 1 is part of leveed-channel
complex 1 (Figs. 4–6). Here, individual rotated blocks are formed
by deformation of pre-existing sediment waves on the levee of a
large leveed-channel complex. Area 2 is east of the leveed-
channel complexes, where two small, nearly complete MTDs
with headward escarpments, chaotic reflection patterns, inter-
preted lateral flow lines, mounding, and compressive pressure
ridges are interpreted as debrites (Fig. 5). Area 3 is in a central
area, west of Area 2 (Fig. 5). Here, portions of two relatively large
surficial MTDs contain large glide blocks on the seafloor in a

For this paper, we follow the general terminology used by
Weimer and Slatt (2006) for the various facies present in MTDs;
these include rotated blocks, glide blocks, thrust blocks, and
outrunner blocks; and a matrix of chaotic sediments (interpreted
as debrite), as well as headward escarpments or scarps at the
FIG. 5.—Coherency map of seafloor overlaid with diagram showing main areas of mass-transport deposits (in brown). Red line shows
location of Figure 6. Study areas 2 and 3 are indicated by red boxes. Map is 35 km by 50 km in size.
FIG. 6.—Schematic cross section showing diagrammatic leveed-channel complexes and mass-transport deposits. Most of the MTDs

are at or near the present-day seafloor. Channel numbers coincide with those of Figure 4. Sediment waves on the eastern levee
of leveed channel 1 have been deformed by localized rotated blocks. Colors diagrammatically separate leveed-channel complexes
and their related sediments. See Figure 4 for location of section. Section is 36 km long and about 700 m thick.

An isopach map of levee thickness for leveed-channel com-
plex 1 (Fig. 8, located in inset area of Fig. 7) shows details of the
highly asymmetric thickness development of the outer levees on
channel bends, both at the westward bend described above, and
the slight southern bend down-channel from the western bend, as
turbidites overflow the outer levees during deposition. Levees on
the inner flanks of the bends are thinner than those on the outer
flanks, and are marked by arcuate slump patterns as the levee
walls are eroded. The slumped material probably contributes to
MTDs in the channel-fill itself.

matrix of chaotic seismic facies. Also in Area 3, older buried
MTDs are illustrated in a series of volume-rendered images
showing sharp headward detachments and lateral boundaries of
MTDs, and slide blocks of varying angularity and size.

Area 1 highlights the development of sediment waves on the
levee of a large leveed-channel complex that were deformed by
development of localized rotated blocks on the distal flanks of the
sediment waves. The area of detailed description is an inset of
buried leveed-channel complex 1 and associated sediment-wave
deposition and slumping (Fig. 7). The highlighted area is a
coherency map of the top of buried leveed-channel complex 1,
which is about 400 m below the seafloor.

Narrow grooved patterns are very evident in the thick
eastern levee system. They may represent headward develop-
ment of slumping along narrow detachment surfaces, possibly
augmented by overbank channel splays. A seismic profile across
leveed-channel complex 1 (Fig. 9) shows a central channel area
that is filled by irregular high-amplitude reflections interpreted
as coarse channel-fill deposits. An overlying level of high-
amplitude channel fill occurs between low-amplitude fill zones.
This zone may be an MTD formed by slumping of the adjoining
levee. The wedge-shaped levees flanking the channel thin away
from the channel axis. Leveed-channel complex 1 is bounded on
either side and below by several older leveed-channel com-
plexes and possible interbedded MTDs. These multiple occur-
rences suggest a long history of leveed-channel deposition from
the canyon area to the north (Figs. 1, 3).

Leveed-channel complex 1 shows an interesting pattern of
sediment waves developed on the outer levee of a westward
bend of the channel (Fig. 7). Presumably the sediment waves
were formed by turbidity flows that overflowed the levee of the
outer channel bends. The sediment waves are largest in the
proximal edge of the levee and decrease in amplitude away
from the channel to the south. Imbricate slumping of individual
sediment waves accentuates the wave patterns, especially in
two narrow grooves cutting from north to south across the
levee.
FIG. 7.—Coherency map of the seafloor, with highlighted central area 1 of buried leveed-channel complex 1 (Figs. 4, 6). Green overlay

is sub-seafloor coherency map of top of buried leveed-channel complex. In this inset area, the central channel is flanked by levees.
Prominent sediment waves occur on the eastern levee, many of which have been deformed by imbricate slumping of rotated
blocks along individual sediment waves. At least two narrow north–south grooves of more highly deformed sediment waves
occur. Map is 35 km by 50 km in size.
FIG. 8.—Isopach map of levees in leveed-channel complex 1. Levees are thickest (reds and yellows) on outer flanks of channel bends

(red arrow). These thick areas coincide with the best-developed sediment waves. Distance between sediment waves ranges up
to 0.5 km. Narrow grooves in thick eastern levee consist of sediment waves deformed by minor listric faults. The seismic profiles
in Figures 9 through 12 illustrate stratigraphic details. Map is about 13 km wide.

A series of three north–south seismic profiles across the leveed-
channel complex and its southern levee shows variations in devel-
opment of sediment waves on the levee (Figs. 10–12). The
westernmost section (Fig. 10) shows only minor development of
sediment waves, observable on the southern end of the section. The
central part of the levee contains well-developed sediment waves
extending down the levee flank for 6 km (Fig. 11). These sediment
waves have been deformed by minor local slip along small listric
normal faults forming rotated blocks along the individual syncli-
nal limbs of the waves and dying out at the base of the levee.

The easternmost section (Fig. 12) is oriented along one of the
narrow north–south grooves across the levee (see Figures 7 and
8 for location of grooves). Sediment waves have been markedly
deformed by local normal faulting of the synclinal axes of the
waves, forming a series of rotated blocks. The listric faults appear
to sole out along a detachment surface at the base of the levee.
Younger sediments of the levee system above the interpreted unit
have also been folded and faulted. This pattern is consistent with
early stages of mass-transport activity. A later phase of erosion by
a mass-transport deposit is evident with its base eroding upper-
most parts of the sediment waves (to be discussed below).

As a summary map for leveed-channel complex 1, a volume-
rendered image is composed over an interval that includes both
channel-fill and levee deposits (Fig. 13). This map allows a

comparison of the high amplitudes of the channel-fill reflections
with the slightly lower amplitudes of the sediment waves.

The high-amplitude reflections of the channel-fill sediments
(yellows, greens, and reds) contrast with the slightly lower ampli-
tudes of the sediment waves. This character extends eastward
from the channel axis for more than 8 km, before passing into the
brown amplitudes of the thin levee flank. These contrasts are
possible using volume-rendering techniques within a time inter-
val of seismic data whereby the data are partially transparent.
The highest amplitudes are weighted highest, and low ampli-
tudes and zero crossings are weighted lowest, allowing emphasis
on differing stratigraphic elements. Individual channel-fill me-
anders in the channel fairway as well as sediment waves in the
levee system are evident.

Sediment waves have been studied in detail for both seafloor
examples and ancient turbidite systems (Normark et al., 1980;
Piper and Normark, 1983; Migeon et al., 2000; Posamentier and
Kolla, 2003). In contrast to previous papers, this paper presents an
example of sediment-wave architecture, deformed by localized
slumping into a type of MTD. In this example, it appears that an
MTD can be initiated by forming rotated blocks, deforming
individual sediment waves in preferred levee positions in leveed-
channel complexes. The greatest deformation occurs in narrow
grooved patterns that may represent zones of block rotation and
FIG. 9.—Seismic profile across leveed-channel complex 1: A) uninterpreted; B) interpreted. Asymmetric levees flank the channel.

Sediment waves occur on the eastern levee but are not apparent on this strike line. Probable slumping of levee walls to form an
MTD in the channel is evident. Other possible MTDs occur interbedded with uninterpreted leveed-channel complexes below
channel 1. Inset map shows location of profile.
FIG. 10.—Seismic profile across eastern levee of leveed-channel complex 1: A) uninterpreted; B) interpreted. In this westernmost
location, sediment waves occur only on southern (distal) end of levee. See inset map for location.
FIG. 11.—Seismic profile across eastern levee of leveed-channel complex 1 with well-developed sediment waves in close proximity

to the channel: A) uninterpreted; B) interpreted. Minor local slip forming rotated blocks is interpreted along individual synclinal
limbs of the sediment waves. See inset map for central location of profile.
FIG. 12.—Seismic profile across eastern levee of leveed-channel complex 1 along narrow grooves of sediment waves deformed by

minor listric faults, forming a series of rotated blocks: A) uninterpreted; B) interpreted. Sediment waves are deformed by
slumping along narrow elongate grooves (see Figs. 7 and 12 for location of grooves), interpreted as listric faulting soling out at
base of levee. See inset map for location of this easternmost profile.
FIG. 13.—Volume-rendered map of leveed-channel complex 1. A blending of peaks and troughs of the seismic wavelets from a depth

interval of the seismic amplitude volume contrasts the internal geometries of both channel-fill and levee sediments. Channel axis
is shown by red arrow. Within the central channel fairway (yellows, reds, and greens) individual segments of channel-fill
sediments make a composite pattern of channel fill. Lower amplitudes of the levee system (blues and browns) outline sediment-
wave patterns over a broad area to the east before low-amplitude browns become dominant in the thinner levee flanks. The
western levee system is thinner and narrower than the eastern levee, lacks as many sediment waves, and shows fewer
stratigraphic patterns. Map is 13 km wide.

slip along a detachment surface at the base of the levee. Amal-
gamation of these zones of slip may produce a mappable unit
over preferred parts of the levee (Figs. 8, 13).

abrupt. The MTD thickens down dip, and the internal reflection
pattern is low-amplitude and discontinuous, indicating disturbed
bedding. This character occurs especially in distal areas, where
pressure ridges are observed (Fig. 15). The down-dip edge of the
MTD is not reached by the end of seismic coverage.

A transverse view of MTD 1 shows a pinch-out edge to the
west, and an abrupt lateral termination to the east at a strike-slip
fault (Fig. 17). This eastern fault termination is part of a well-
developed shear zone (Fig. 15). Shear patterns in Figure 15
suggest left-lateral movement, consistent with down-dip move-
ment of the MTD to the south. Several smaller MTDs, including
MTD 2, have amalgamated into the larger feature mapped as
MTD 1 (Fig. 17).

Area 2, east of the leveed-channel complexes, contains two
small, nearly complete MTDs on the seafloor. These MTDs contain
headward escarpments, chaotic reflection patterns, interpreted
lateral flow lines, mounding, and compressive pressure ridges,
and are interpreted as debrites (Figs. 14, 15). An oblique view of the
seafloor (Fig. 15) gives a better image of the two MTDs. MTD 2 is
outlined. MTD 1 lies to the east (right). Interpreted elongate flow
lines occur parallel to the length of the MTDs, and pressure ridges
are well developed at the terminations of the MTDs.

MTD 2 is small, thin, superposed on MTD 1, and almost
contained in its entire length within the 3D survey (Fig. 15). It is
initiated at a fault scarp at its northern end, contains longitudinal
flow lines along most of its length, and has well-developed
transverse compressive pressure ridges near its southern termi-
nus, where the deposit becomes thicker (Figs. 15, 18). Irregular
bathymetry and wavy bedding indicate compressive patterns.
The decrease in gradient from 1.3° to 0.66° on the seafloor occurs

Several depositional features of MTD 1 can be observed on an
elongate longitudinal seismic profile along the axis of the MTD
(Fig. 16). Up-dip inception of the deposit at the fault scarp is quite
FIG. 14.—Coherency map of the seafloor showing the location of Area 2 (shaded green). Two MTDs (1 and 2) are shown. See Figure
15 for oblique view of MTDs. Map is 50 km by 35 km in size.
FIG. 15.—Coherency map of the seafloor (oblique view) looking towards the north-northeast at MTDs 1 and 2. The coherency map

shows details of MTDs originating from fault scarps, with interpreted flow lines and pressure ridges. MTD 2 is outlined in black.
It is 16.25 km long and 1 km wide. MTD 1, to the east, is more extensive and consists of several amalgamated smaller MTDs,
including MTD 2 (Figs. 16, 17). The easternmost MTD is flanked by a fault scarp and a shear zone, suggesting strike-slip motion
along the flank of the MTD.
FIG. 16.—Seismic profile along longitudinal section of MTD 1: A) uninterpreted; B) interpreted (location on inset map). The deposit

has a well-defined headward fault scarp, a low-amplitude, discontinuous internal seismic character, a distal thickness bulge, and
a well-defined top and base. The deposit extends for more than 18 km, with a thickness increasing from 50 m to 100 m until
termination of seismic coverage. Other MTDs and slumped leveed-channel complexes underlie the interpreted seafloor MTD.
Location of profile is shown in inset map.
FIG. 17.—Northeast–southwest seismic profile in a transverse section across compressional zone of MTD 1: A) uninterpreted; B)

interpreted. MTD is bounded to the east by an abrupt fault scarp and to the west by a pinch-out on a pre-existing topographic
high. Several smaller MTDs, including MTD 2, are amalgamated within MTD 1 (location in inset map).
FIG. 18.—Longitudinal seismic profile along the axis of MTD 2: A) uninterpreted; B) interpreted. Location is shown on inset map. MTD

2 is thin and superposed on MTD 1. Compressive pressure ridges are present at the toe of the flow where depositional dip
decreases. Other MTDs and leveed-channel complexes below MTD 2 show various types of mass-transport patterns. The length
of the shallow MTD is 16 km.

at the onset of the compressive zone, and may be controlled by
thickening of the underlying MTD (Fig. 18). A transverse section
across MTD 2 shows that it is thin, consisting of a central sag with
only one reflection below the strong seafloor reflection (Fig. 19).

In summary, MTD 1 is more than 16 km long and 9.6 km wide,
with thickness from 30 m to 100 m. Its eastern boundary is
represented by an abrupt strike-slip fault. MTD 2 is much smaller
and is superposed on MTD 1. It is about 16 km long, with widths
from 0.8 km to 1.6 km. Both MTDs 1 and 2 are initiated along
abrupt updip fault scarps. Internal seismic patterns gradually
change from breakup of fairly continuous segments in the proxi-
mal portions of the MTDs to more chaotic and opaque patterns in
the more distal portions, interpreted to reflect decrease in size and
integrity of slide blocks. Interpreted sediment flow direction is
indicated by longitudinal ridges on the surfaces of MTDs. Distal
parts of the MTDs are thicker and develop compressive pressure
ridges as gradient decreases, in this case from 1.3° to 0.66°.

Area 3 includes MTDs in a central area between those of Area
2 and the leveed-channel complexes to the west (Fig. 20). These
MTDs are laterally more extensive than those of Area 2, and are
marked by irregular seafloor bathymetry, suggesting large bro-
ken slide blocks in these MTDs. Inferred slide blocks in MTD 1 are
larger than those in MTD 2. The two MTDs are separated by a
marked north–south-oriented narrow shear zone and linear bathy-
metric break, with MTD 1 bathymetrically lower than MTD 2. The
western part of MTD 1 is incised by the youngest leveed-channel
complex (leveed-channel complex 5, Fig. 4).

An oblique close-up view of Area 3 illustrates the irregular
seafloor bathymetry interpreted as large slide blocks, particu-
larly in the area of MTD 1 (Fig. 21). A transverse seismic section
across MTDs 1 and 2 shows the irregular seafloor surface and
internal discontinuous reflection patterns, interpreted as large
slide blocks in a matrix of smaller blocks (Fig. 22). These MTDs are
amalgamated into an underlying larger flow. The two MTDs are
separated by the topographically high crest of an underlying
series of leveed-channel complexes. The entire profile below MTDs
1 and 2 appears to consist of older MTDs and slumped leveed-
channel complexes (Fig. 22). This succession suggests a relatively
long-lived period of MTD development (see later discussion).

Leveed-channel complex 5 is present on the seafloor to the
west and incises into MTD 1. The position of this leveed-channel
complex may have been partially controlled by the position of the
MTD. An oblique seafloor view from the northwest shows the
shear zone separating MTDs 1 and 2 and the bathymetrically lower
position of MTD 1. The irregular bathymetry of MTD 1 is inter-
preted to be formed by large glide blocks in the MTD (Fig. 23).

A longitudinal (north–south) seismic profile down the length
of MTD 1 shows the 50-m-thick zone of large glide blocks,
transported down the unstable seafloor slope (Fig. 24). MTD 1
overlies a series of other MTDs and slumped leveed-channel
complexes in varying stages of deformation on this very unstable
depositional surface.
Volume-Rendered Images of Older MTDs in Area 3

A series of thick amalgamated MTDs underlies MTDs 1 and 2
in Area 3 (Figs. 22, 24). These MTDs show interesting detailed
relationships to their headward and lateral bounding edges and
their internal seismic facies patterns, some of which are shown in

a series of volume-rendered slabs (Figs. 25–28). Volume render-
ing of 3D seismic data highlights sediments by removing specific
amplitudes and leaving a 3D volume of only peak or trough
amplitudes. By systematically slicing through the seismic data,
selected deepwater stratigraphic elements are highlighted in
order of depth (or time). The volume is best seen using a data set,
flattened on the seafloor in order to stay as parallel as possible to
stratigraphic elements. A seismic chair display illustrates a verti-
cal section of four flattened volume-rendered layers A, B, C, and
D from oldest to youngest, each 50 m thick (Fig. 25). The oldest
layer is also shown in oblique plan view. The rendered layers are
best viewed in a series of plan-view maps (Fig. 26).

Four volume-rendered flattened depth layers reveal many
aspects of the development of the MTDs (Fig. 26). These layers
occur at depths below the seafloor from 125 m to 25 m, respec-
tively, showing successively younger slices (oldest to youngest in
Fig. 26A–F). Two portions of MTDs (left and right in each image
of Fig. 26) are distinctly separated by the top of the underlying
leveed-channel complex (visible in Fig. 26 and described in Fig.
22). The abrupt eastern boundary of the eastern MTD is distinct
in slabs D through B (Fig. 26), as is the northern detachment scar
at the inception of the MTD.

The seismic facies of the eastern MTD in proximal areas to the
north is marked by fracturing and breakup of large rafted glide
blocks of bedded material which appear to have moved only
slightly, especially in older layers A and B. This pattern passes to
the south into smaller blocks. Well-developed transverse com-
pressive pressure ridges also occur, especially at the distal end of
the MTD. The eastern edge of the MTD is abrupt, as blocks of
bedded material are sheared off the bounding wall and incorpo-
rated into the MTD. The MTD to the west appears to be more
homogeneous, with smaller blocks and some pressure ridges.

Details of the abrupt headward detachment scarp of the
eastern MTD and the lateral detachment along its eastern flank
are striking both in map view and in seismic profiles (Fig. 27, map
view A, profiles B and C). Internal facies patterns of the MTD are
best seen in the eastern part of the map (Fig. 27A), consisting of
larger slide blocks in a matrix of smaller blocks. Some large glide
blocks occur in the upper part of the MTD above the level of the
map (Section B). The blocks become smaller down-dip. In another
area (Section C), an abrupt breakaway occurs along the headward
scarp, and the size of the glide blocks is mostly small.

Details of the abrupt eastern edge of the eastern MTD (Fig. 26)
are shown on the volume-rendered map view (Fig. 28). The
seismic profile shows the same abrupt boundary separating the
chaotic discontinuous seismic facies of the MTD from the hori-
zontally bedded undisturbed stratigraphy outside the MTD to
the east (Fig. 28B). A small sub-unit on the seismic profile (Fig.
28B) at the eastern edge of the MTD is imaged in the map view as
a separate amalgamated unit with well-developed compressive
pressure ridges. The map view also shows transition from a
headward detachment scarp into fractured slide blocks of bed-
ded material, which have been moved only slightly before being
broken gradually into finer blocks to the south and incorporated
into pressure ridges (Fig. 28A). Large individual blocks have
dimensions from 0.5 km to 1 km.

In summary, two MTDs on the seafloor, containing large slide
blocks, occur in Area 3. Both MTDs begin with headward detach-
ment scarps, which pass through a proximal zone of large broken
blocks of bedded material. These features have a small lateral
movement into distal areas of smaller blocks and interpreted
debrite, and well-developed compressive pressure ridges. The
two MTDs are separated by a shear zone, apparently controlled
by the crest of an underlying leveed-channel complex. Large slide
blocks in the MTDs are well imaged on the seafloor.

is shown on inset map. The flow is widest and thickest in its compressive toe, with dimensions of 1.5 km width and 30 m thickness.
Underlying MTDs have abrupt edges, with residual bedded segments between MTDs.
FIG. 20.—Coherency map of the seafloor showing the highlighted location of Area 3 with MTDs 1 and 2. Seafloor bathymetry is highly

irregular, suggesting large broken slide blocks in these MTDs. The two MTDs are separated by a shear zone and break in seafloor
topography. Map dimensions are 50 km by 35 km.
FIG. 21.—Coherency map of seafloor showing an oblique view to the north–northeast. The bathymetry is highly disrupted by

interpreted glide blocks on the surface, especially in MTD 1. MTDs are separated by a north–south-trending shear zone. MTD 1
is bathymetrically slightly lower than MTD 2. MTD 1 is bounded on the west by leveed-channel complex 5. Map is about 30 km
wide. Location of Figure 22 is indicated by orange transverse line.
FIG. 22.—East–west seismic profile across MTDs 1 and 2: A) uninterpreted; B) interpreted. The topographic high separating MTDs

1 and 2 appears to be a high part of the underlying leveed-channel complex. Amalgamated MTDs underlying MTDs 1 and 2
comprise more than 150 m of vertical section, and lie above a series of slumped leveed-channel complexes. To the left (west),
amalgamated MTDs are incised by leveed-channel complex 5. Profile is about 30 km wide. See Figure 21 and inset map (Fig. 22)
for location.
FIG. 23.—Coherency map of the seafloor of Area 3 in an oblique view from the west–northwest. The map shows the area of irregular

seafloor interpreted as large glide blocks in MTD 1 and the shear zone separating MTDs 1 and 2. The yellow line marks the location
of a longitudinal seismic profile (Fig. 24) down the length of MTD 1. Map is about 18 km wide.

More deeply buried MTDs underlying the MTDs on the
seafloor are illustrated by volume-rendered images. They show
well-developed headward fault-scarp detachment surfaces. A
distinct shear boundary flanks the eastern side of one flow, with
an abrupt vertical edge. Slide blocks sheared off the bounding
wall are incorporated into the MTD. The development of succes-
sive zones of MTDs and slumped leveed-channel complexes
considerably deeper than the illustrated units suggests a long-
term sediment instability at the mouth of the canyon. Both
leveed-channel complexes and neighboring slope sediments are
subject to slumping and incorporation into MTDs in this unstable
depositional environment. Possible controls on the development
of MTDs are discussed below.

Many authors have described the processes by which MTDs
are formed (summarized by Moscardelli et al., 2006). Several of
these processes could have been acting together to produce
MTDs in the study area. Most probable causes include: (1) contin-
ued structural tilting of the seafloor towards the south, because of
activity along toe thrusts of the Niger Delta (Mitchum and Wach,
2002); (2) high sedimentation rates producing instability in an
apron focused at the canyon mouth; and (3) cyclical formation of
MTDs as part of the cyclical deposition associated with relative
falls and rises of sea level.

Structural tilting of the sediments in the study area could
produce major oversteepening of depositional slopes, leading to

mass failure and downslope movement of sediments. Several
examples of MTDs and slumped leveed-channel complexes sug-
gest slope failure that involves relatively thick successions of
sedimentary units (Figs. 16, 18, 24). As noted above, seafloor
topography is strongly controlled by structural patterns of Niger
Delta toe thrusts (Fig. 1), and structural movement is occurring at
present, especially along the outer edge of the outer thrust belt.
Mitchum and Wach (2002) noted that Upper Quaternary leveed-
channel complexes were involved in folding along the outer
thrust belt.

Relatively high rates of deposition were focused at the canyon
mouth, forming an apron of thick sediments. This condition
would tend to steepen depositional gradients and create instabil-
ity in the sedimentary apron. This steepening, combined with
structural tilting, would lead to significant instability of the slope.
A gradient of 1.3° was measured in one MTD in the study area
(Fig. 18). Mass failure seems to be concentrated in an area spread-
ing out from a focus at the canyon mouth, suggesting that the
thicker mud-rich sediments in this area are more prone to failure
(Fig. 3).

Several workers (e.g., Weimer, 1990; Beaubeouf and
Friedmann, 2000; Posamentier and Kolla, 2003; Moscardelli et
al., 2006) have suggested that MTDs appear to be an integral
part of the pattern of sedimentation attributed to cyclical rela-
tive falls and rises of sea level. During early parts of relative
falls, shelf and slope sediments tend to be more subject to
erosion and mass failures. MTDs resulting from these failures
may be emplaced in lower slope and basin positions during the
FIG. 24.—Longitudinal seismic profile of MTD 1: A) uninterpreted; B) interpreted. Profile is about 18 km long. MTD is about 50 m

thick. Location is shown in inset map. Surface slope is relatively steep (3.15°). Topography is highly irregular, marked by surficial
blocks. Below MTD 1 is a thick zone of MTDs and highly slumped leveed-channel complexes, indicating general instability of the
slope.

layers of a chosen thickness are mapped by the technique of volume rendering to show only peak amplitudes. In this example,
four layers labeled A through D from oldest to youngest are displayed in a vertical section, and the oldest (A) is displayed in a
volume-rendered oblique plan view.
FIG. 26.—Four volume-rendered flattened depth slabs from Area 3 (Figure 20). Each slab is 25 m thick: A) 100–125 m; B) 75–100 m;

C) 50–75 ; D) 25–50 m in depth. Images are 23 km wide. Maps show features of MTDs from A to D (oldest to youngest). In slabs
A through C, the underlying leveed-channel complex (LCC) is visible. In slabs A and B, headward and lateral fault boundaries
are mostly well defined. Internal seismic facies of eastern MTD grades southward from extremely large angular slide blocks with
little displacement, to smaller blocks in pressure ridges. In slab B, upper portions of the eastern MTD consist of pressure ridges.
The western MTD is composed mostly of homogeneous small slide blocks with poorly defined pressure ridges.
FIG. 27.—A) Volume-rendered map of part of eastern MTD showing details of extremely abrupt headward detachment scarp, lateral

edge, and internal facies. Locations of Parts B and C are shown. Map is 5 km wide and 8 km long. B) Northwest–southeast-oriented
seismic profile showing very abrupt headward detachment scarp and internal seismic facies of the MTD, which consists of several

first part of the cycle of deposition. Subsequently, theses fea-
tures become overlain by sheet sands, amalgamated channels,
and leveed-channel complexes of the lowstand systems tract
(mass-transport complexes of Weimer, 1990). Although cycli-
cally interbedded MTDs were not described in the study area,
some seismic profiles (e.g., Fig. 9) show possible MTDs in
cyclically repetitive positions. As part of this cycle, increased
turbid flow and mass transport of sediment down the channels
during early lowstand time would induce erosion and under-
cutting of channel thalwegs. This activity would lead to slump-
ing of canyon walls into channels (Figs. 3, 9).

the study of these areas, different possible mechanisms for the
emplacement of the MTDs have been identified.

Some MTDs can be initiated by slumping of oversteepened
sediment waves in preferred positions on leveed-channel com-
plexes. Other MTDs have sheet-like geometries, and are com-
monly amalgamated. They originate from distinct headward
escarpment surfaces and are propagated along basal detachment
surfaces. Seismic facies of these MTDs may begin with large
broken slide blocks of bedded material, and pass distally into
finer blocks and gradually into a chaotic seismic facies inter-
preted as debrite. Longitudinal surface patterns in mid-flow
positions of interpreted debrites are interpreted as lateral flow
lines. A compressive toe may have transverse pressure ridges and
a thickness bulge. Decreases in slope gradient from 1.3o to 0.66o
are enough to initiate compressive pressure ridges.

Upper Quaternary MTDs and leveed-channel complexes domi-
nate the seafloor and shallow subsurface at the mouth of a major
shelf–slope canyon of the offshore Niger Delta. MTDs overlie and
are interbedded with leveed-channel complexes in a synchronous
relationship. A 3D seismic survey at the mouth of the canyon gives
excellent detailed images of these features. Geomorphic observa-
tions are enhanced with a 3D visualization, volume-rendering
technique to image internal and external seismic-scale patterns.
Three areas of interest provide excellent examples of MTDs. From

Some MTDs are bounded laterally by abrupt vertical surfaces
along which mass-transport movement presumably occurred,
and large blocks torn from the bounding walls are incorporated
into the mass-transport sediments. Inferred flow paths are influ-
enced by bounding topographic areas of high relief, and MTDs
commonly lap out against such high-relief areas.

The wholesale development of MTDs in this local area is
probably related to continued seaward structural tilting, and
FIG. 28.—A) Volume-rendered amplitude map of part of eastern MTD (Fig. 25) showing details of the eastern edge, including an

abrupt lateral edge, a narrow north–south peripheral slump zone, and an internal seismic facies of slide blocks in various sizes
and stages of fracture. Location of seismic profile (B) is shown. Map is 8 km wide. B) Seismic profile across map area (A) showing
abrupt vertical eastern edge of MTD, a narrow peripheral zone of pressure ridges, and internal seismic facies of the MTD. Map
layer is shown. Profile is about 8 km long.

to steep gradients and sediment instability produced by in-
creased sedimentation rates at the mouth of the canyon. This
instability is reflected not only in development of individual
mass-flow units, but also probably in movement of the entire
depositional apron at the canyon mouth. This movement is
suggested by the bounding faults of the depositional apron
(Fig. 3).

Detailed depositional patterns visible in high-frequency seis-
mic imaging of seafloor deposits can be analogs for visualizing
stratigraphic relationships in deeply buried reservoirs, where
seismic resolution does not allow imaging such detail.
